#Text=Avoid the Urge to Upgrade Your Computer

#Text=Have you been feeling your PC is n't enough lately , maybe you read an article in a PC magazine in which a writer boasts of his $ 3000 computer , with water cooling , and neon-lights running through the casing ?
#Text=Or maybe you 're having trouble resisting the urge to buy that featured video card at the Newegg Online Store ?
#Text=Sometimes upgrades are n't worth it , you may only appreciate them for one game , then wish you had the money back .
#Text=This article will help you resist the urge to constantly upgrade your computer every time you get money .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Tweak your operating system .
#Text=There are many ways to increase the performance of your current computer without having to pay for an upgrade .
#Text=Here 's a good article to refer to for Windows Vista users .
#Text=Many of the tips in that article will also work for both Windows XP and Windows 7 users
#Text=Think about the reasons you want to upgrade .
#Text=Did you see a game like Crysis , and you were drooling over the quality of the visuals ?
#Text=If so , try games known for their storyline or multiplayer gameplay , not their graphics .
#Text=Some good examples would be :
#Text=Half Life 2 , a game set in post-apocalyptic Europe , it 's known for an amazing storyline .
#Text=Team Fortress 2 , this game is an extremely popular multiplayer game , well known for its excellent class design .

#Text=Thief : The Dark Project and Thief 2 , both are very old 3D games , do n't expect good visuals , but they too have an amazing storyline , set in a Victorian-Steampunk world in which you are a thief .
#Text=Age of Empires 1 and 2 , amazing strategy games in which you lead civilizations to expansion and conquest of either computer players or people online !
#Text=Plants vs Zombies , an extremely addictive tower-defense style game in which you build plants to protect your backyard from zombies , this game will even run on Netbooks !
#Text=Overclocking is another way , albeit risky , to improve your computer 's performance .
#Text=It involves forcing components ( usually the CPU , but video cards can be overclocked as well ) to perform calculations at higher speeds than their factory defaults .
#Text=This can put your computer at risk though , especially if you mess around with voltages .
#Text=Whatever you do , do n't attempt to overclock a laptop CPU as your computer will overheat quickly .
#Text=If you do end up upgrading , do n't bother upgrading components that wo n't show a significant improvement in performance .
#Text=An example of a component that wo n't drastically improve speed is the motherboard .
#Text=Unless your existing motherboard is the lowest of low-end hardware , it should have good performance .
#Text=Find a hobby that does n't require a high-performance computer .
#Text=A good example is computer programming , not only will it provide huge job opportunities if you become good at it , it will also provide a constructive use of your time .
#Text=When you make a decision to buy a computer component ( i. e Video card ) , make sure that it is what you want and will be good enough to last at least a year .

#Text=Sometimes when you find a deal on a computer component , you rush to buy it and in your excitement , you do n't realize that maybe it does n't have a DVI port , and you were planning on buying a new monitor this year .
#Text=Now , when you go to buy the monitor , and it needs a DVI connection , you will have to buy a new video card .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Do n't torture yourself by browsing online stores for parts when you do n't need them .
#Text=You might end up buying something you do n't need , like a gold-plated DVI cord .

#Text=Do n't feel bad about upgrading if your computer seriously needs it , this article assumes you already have a decent computer , if your computer is 10 years old or is a slow laptop , go ahead get a new one .
